page.title: 09FARMING IN GLENLIVET
page.content: The principle forms of agriculture in Glenlivet are beef cattle and sheep. {Grass} is conserved mainly as silage although some hay is made when the weather is favourable.Turnips also provide food for the winter along with the grain from barley and oats, while the straw provides bedding. {Calves}are reared and sold at about one year old in the store market to farmers at lower altitudes who specialise in fattening cattle. During the winter which can be very severe the cattle are kept inside. {Sheep}are mainly outwintered. Lambs are born in March or April when hopefully the worst of the winter is past, and sold around September and October. The farms are run by the family with casual labour employed at busy times.
